Mr. Flanagan asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice and ordered to be printed. A Bill Making an appropriation to indemnify the citizens of Brenham, Washington County, Texas, for loss of private property by fire and pillage at the hands of United States soldiers. Whereas the town of Brenham, Washington County, State of Texas, was burned and pillaged by United States soldiers on the night of the seventh of September, eighteen hundred and sixty-six; and whereas such wanton destruction of private property by the authorities of the United States in time of peace is at enmity with the fundamental principles of our Government, and contrary to our demands on other governments for like spoliations to our citizens: Therefore,

Mr. Sawyer asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice and ordered to be printed. A Bill Authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to pay to the claimants the proceeds of certain cotton seized in violation of instructions from the Treasury Department, and which have been erroneously covered into the Treasury. Whereas the Secretary of the Treasury, by a circular letter of instructions to the agents of that Department, bearing date June twenty-seventh, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, prohibited the seizure of any cotton by such agents after the receipt thereof, directing the return of "all property or money received or collected" after the thirteenth day of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, east of the Mississippi River, and after the twenty-fourth of June west of said river, and terminating the existence of said agencies after the thirtieth day of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-five; and whereas certain lots of cotton were seized by such agents long after their removal from office, and without authority of law, the proceeds of which have been covered into the Treasury: Therefore,

A Bill Relative to a harbor of refuge and breakwater at the entrance of the Cape Cod ship-canal. Whereas the legislature of Massachusetts has by law incorporated the Gape Cod Ship-Canal Company, for the purpose of constructing and operating a ship-canal from Barnstable Bay to Buzzard's Bay, to be about eight miles long and twenty-three feet depth of water, at an expense of over seven million dollars; and whereas a breakwater at the eastern entrance of said canal will be a necessity as a harbor of refuge, the construction of which at the public expense, for the protection of the immense commerce as ships and vessels of war using the same, would accord with the long-established policy of the Government; and whereas the State of Massachusetts, and many persons interested in the commerce of the North Atlantic coast, have urged upon Congress the propriety and necessity of the United States assuming the expense of constructing such breakwater and harbor of refuge: Therefore,

Mr. Pratt asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Relative to claims of certain northern creditors. Whereas the Congress of the Confederate States ordered the sequestration and confiscation of all the debts due and owing, from inhabitants of the Southern States engaged in rebellion, to their creditors residing in the loyal States; and whereas under general order number forty, issued by Major General Butler, from his headquarters at New Orleans) on June six, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, there was seized in the hands of different banks in said city, as large sums of money, the proceeds of the confiscation of northern credits, deposited in said banks to the credit of the Confederate States receivers, which sum ought to be distributed in ratable proportions among such loyal creditors whose debts were thus confiscated, and who have not been able since the close of the rebellion to collect the same from their debtors; and whereas the Secretary of the Treasury is of the opinion that he has no power to distribute this money among the creditors entitled to the same, and determine the rights of each to his portion thereof without further legislation, and said money has been in the Treasury of the United States since the month of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, to the great injury of the lawful owners thereof, although they have made repeated applications for the same: Now, therefore,

Mr. Pratt asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and and ordered to be printed. Reported by Mr. Pratt, with amendments, viz: Strike out the word in [brackets] and insert the words printed in italics. A Bill Relative to claims of certain northern creditors. Whereas the Congress of the Confederate States ordered the sequestration and confiscation of all the debts due and owing, from inhabitants of the Southern States engaged in rebellion, to their creditors residing in the loyal States; and Whereas under General Orders number forty, issued by Major-General Butler, from his headquarters at New Orleans, on June sixth, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, there was seized in the hands of different banks in said city [as] large sums of money, the proceeds of the confiscation of northern credits, deposited in said banks to the credit of the Confederate States treasurer or receivers, which sums ought to be distributed in ratable proportions among such loyal creditors whose debts were thus confiscated, and who have not been able since the close of the rebellion to collect the same from their debtors; and Whereas the Secretary of the Treasury is of the opinion that he has no power to distribute this money among the creditors entitled to the same and determine the rights of each to his portion thereof without further legislation, and said money has been in the Treasury of the United States since the month of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, to the great injury of the lawful owners thereof, although they have made repeated applications for the same: Now, therefore,

Mr. Pratt asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims. and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of those suffering from the destruction of the salt works near Manchester, Kentucky, pursuant to the orders of Major General Carlos Buell. Whereas, on the sixteenth day of February, eighteen hundred and sixty-three, the Adjutant General, by order of the Secretary of War, made the following order: "Ordered, That William P. Thomasson, esquire, of Louisville, Kentucky, be, and he is hereby, authorized to investigate and report to this Department, the value of the Goose Creek Salt Mills, destroyed by the order of Major General Buell, in Kentucky; that he give notice to the proprietors or their agents of the time and place at which he will receive testimony; and that he take such further testimony on the part of the Government as may be necessary to protect the rights and interests of the Government, as well upon the point of value as of the loyalty of the proprietors to the Government of the United States." And whereas the said commissioner, on the thirteenth day of May following, submitted his report to the Secretary of War, in which he estimated the injuries done to the several salt wells, their pumps and pipes, the deterioration to the furnaces and fixtures, and the value of the salt and salt barrels destroyed and in which, also, he estimated and allowed such sums as would have been realized from the production of salt, but for such destruction, for the period of eight months succeeding the date of destruction. And whereas he classified in his schedule his allowances, as follows, to wit:--Case number one: The United States to T. T. Garrard, debtor, for injury to well, pump, pipe, and so forth, five hundred dollars; for one hundred and twenty four salt barrels, at forty cents each, forty-nine dollars and sixty cents; for six thousand three hundred bushels of salt destroyed, at fifty cents per bushel, three thousand one hundred and fifty dollars; for deterioration of furnace and fixtures by non-usage, five hundred dollars; for nine thousand two hundred bushels salt, the anticipated yield for eight months, at fifty cents, nine thousand six hundred dollars, making a total of thirteen thousand seven hundred and ninety-nine dollars and sixty cents. Case number two: The United States to James W. Reid, debtor, for injury to well, pump, pipe, and so forth, five hundred dollars; for five thousand bushels salt destroyed, two thousand five hundred dollars; for deterioration of furnaces and fixtures, five hundred dollars; for eleven thousand two hundred bushels salt, the anticipated yield for eight months, five thousand six hundred dollars, making a total of nine thousand one hundred dollars. Case number three: The United States to White, Horton and Garrard, debtor, for injury to well, pump, pipe, and so forth, five hundred dollars; for two thousand bushels of salt destroyed, one thousand dollars; for deterioration of furnace and fixtures by non-usage, five hundred and fifty dollars; for sixteen thousand bushels salt, the anticipated yield for eight months, eight thousand dollars, making a total of ten thousand and fifty dollars. Case number four: The United States to Gilson and Chastam, debtor, for injury to well, pump, pipe, and so forth, five hundred dollars; for eight thousand bushels salt destroyed, four thousand dollars; for deterioration by non-usage of furnace and fixtures, five hundred dollars; for nine thousand six hundred bushels salt, the anticipated yield for eight months, four thousand eight hundred dollars, making a total of nine thousand eight hundred dollars. Case number five: The United States to I. and D. White, debtor, for injury to wells, pumps, pipes, and so forth, one thousand dollars; for injury to water-pipe, furnace, and so forth, one thousand dollars; for nine thousand bushels salt destroyed, at fifty cents per bushel, four thousand five hundred dollars; for deterioration by non-usage to furnace and fixtures, five hundred and fifty dollars; for twenty thousand bushels salt, the anticipated yield for eight months, ten thousand dollars, making a total of seventeen thousand and fifty dollars. Case number six: The United States to I. and D. White, survivors, for injury to well, pump, and pipe, five hundred dollars. And whereas said report, under a call of the House of Representatives at the first session of the Thirty-eighth Congress, was furnished by the Secretary of War and printed as Executive Document twenty-nine. And whereas said report of the commissioner has never been acted upon, and the said parties, in favor of whom said allowances were made, were in some cases proprietors and in others lessees, and changes by death, assignment, or otherwise may have occurred during the time which has elapsed since said report was made, and it is desirable that the parties entitled to the sums hereinafter named on account of the injuries and losses aforesaid should be paid: Now, therefore,

Mr. Kellogg asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Relative to the claims of certain northern creditors. Whereas the Congress of the Confederate States ordered the sequestration and confiscation of all the debts due from inhabitants of the Southern States to their creditors residing in the loyal States; and whereas there was paid to the Citizens' Bank of New Orleans, prior to the first day of May, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, a sum exceeding half a million of dollars, the proceeds of such confiscation of northern credits, of which there remained to the credit of the Confederate States receivers, in such bank, the sum of two hundred and nineteen thousand and ninety dollars and ninety-four cents only, on the first day of May, at the time of the occupation of the city of New Orleans by the forces of the United States, which said sum, by the order of the general then commanding the Department of the Gulf, was seized for the benefit of the northern creditors whose debts had been thus confiscated, and said sum was by him sent to the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, to be by him held in trust for the benefit of said northern creditors; and whereas, owing to a doubt entertained by the Secretary of the Treasury as to his legal authority to distribute said sum of two hundred and nineteen thousand and ninety dollars and ninety-four cents among the creditors to whom it belongs, and to determine the rights of each to his portion thereof, the money has lain thus undisturbed in the Treasury since July, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, to the great injury and detriment of the just and lawful owners thereof, although they have made many applications to have the same: Now, therefore,

A Bill To aid in the construction of the Sutro tunnel from the proceeds of the sale of mineral lands. Whereas our public lands contain mines of the precious metals which are unsurpassed in richness, and can with proper development he made speedily to enhance the value of all property, and thereby relieve the burdens of the people; and whereas a wise policy indicates that the revenue derived from our mineral lands should, to some extent, be devoted again to the much-needed development of that important interest; and whereas Congress, by an act approved July twenty-fifth, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, authorized the construction of a draining and exploring tunnel to the Comstock lode, in the State of Nevada, and granted to Adolph Sutro certain rights and privileges, which have been assigned, transferred, and set over to a corporation duly organized under the laws of the State of California, and known as the "Sutro Tunnel Company;" and whereas great benefits will accrue to the people of the United States from the construction of said tunnel, which, as a great geological survey, penetrating into the very bowels of an argentiferous mountain to a greater depth than

Mr. Pratt asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of Phoebe Hepburn. Whereas it is alleged that Phoebe Hepburn was the owner by purchase and assignment of the following bounty land-warrants, issued under the act of March three, eighteen hundred and fifty-five, to wit: Numbers 69896, 59419, 86157, 88619, 91724, 31558, 67417, 59978, 87277, 91707, 17481, and 95320 for one hundred and twenty acres each; and numbers 61881 and 57532 for one hundred and sixty acres each; in all, fourteen warrants; that in the year eighteen hundred and fifty-seven, she placed said warrants in the hands of Salmon Sharp as her agent, to locate or otherwise dispose of them for her; that said agent did sell four of said warrants, to wit, one of the one-hundred-and sixty-acre warrants, and three of the one-hundred-and-twenty-acre warrants, and made a memorandum of their respective numbers, and to whom sold, and placed it among the ten remaining unsold warrants; that by an accident said memorandum and the ten warrants were dropped in a cattle-yard, and were eaten up by the cattle, and, having no other memorandum, he is unable to state the numbers of the warrants that were sold, consequently, cannot arrive at the numbers of the ten warrants that were not sold; and whereas it appears from the records of the General Land Office that warrant number 61881 for one hundred and sixty acres, and numbers 59419 and 17481 for one hundred and twenty acres, being three of the above-named warrants, have been returned to said office located, leaving but one of the sold warrants not accounted for: Therefore,

Whereas the State of Louisiana has contracted with the Louisiana Levee Company, said company agreeing to construct, maintain, repair, and keep in repair, for twenty-one years, all levees necessary for the protection of the alluvial lands of said State from overflow by the waters of the Mississippi River and its tributaries; and whereas it is stipulated in said contract that all new levees shall be located, and the dimensions of all the levees shall be determined by a commission of three engineers to be appointed as follows: One by the governor of the State of Louisiana, one by the said company, and one by the Government of the United States: Therefore,

A Bill To revive the navigation and commercial interests of the United States. Whereas the mercantile marine of the country was nearly destroyed during the late rebellion in consequence of the inability of the Government to protect it; and now, while bearing its share of taxation, has no such protection from foreign competition as is afforded to other great national interests and industries, and is therefore steadily declining; and whereas the restoration of our commercial marine, constituting, as it does, one of the most efficient means of defense in time of war, is of great national importance and essential to the maintenance of our position as a first-class power: Therefore,

Mr. Davis, of West Virginia, asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To reimburse the State of West Virginia for losses incurred by reason of the destruction of its bridges, and so forth, during the late war. Whereas the State of West Virginia, by reason of its being a border State, the dividing line between the then contending armies, and of being alternately in possession of each army, suffered heavy losses during the late civil war in the destruction of bridges, court-houses, churches, and so forth; and whereas said State was loyal to the Government of the United States and contributed her full share toward the putting down of the late rebellion; and whereas the greater portion of said bridges, churches, and so forth, were destroyed by the Federal troops, acting under the orders of their superiors; and whereas said State, although its people are suffering from the want of the rebuilding of said bridges, court-houses, and so forth, being yet young in years, and having to endure a heavy expense in the erection of its public buildings, and so forth, is unable to contribute toward the rebuilding of said works: Therefore,

column10: Mr. Kelly asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Public Lands, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Extending the time for the selection of swamp and overflowed lands in Oregon, under the act of Congress approved March twelfth, eighteen hundred and sixty. Whereas by act of Congress entitled "An act to extend the provisions of 'An act to enable the State of Arkansas and other States to reclaim the swamp-lands within their limits' to Minnesota and Oregon, and for other purposes," approved March twelfth, eighteen hundred and sixty, it was provided "that the selection to be made from lands already surveyed in each of the States, including Minnesota and Oregon, under authority of the act aforesaid, and of the act to aid the State of Louisiana in draining the swamp-lands therein, approved March second, eighteen hundred and forty-nine, shall he made within two years from the adjournment of the legislature of each State at its next session after the date of this act;" and Whereas said period of two years elapsed without any selection of said lands being made on the part of the State of Oregon: Therefore,

Referred to the Committee on Public Lands and ordered to be printed. Amendment Intended to be proposed by Mr. Corbett to the bill (S. 383) extending the time for the selection of swamp and overflowed lands in Oregon, under act of Congress approved March twelfth, eighteen hundred and sixty, viz: Insert the following proviso:

Mr. Vickers asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To incorporate the Washington Canal and Water-Power Company. Whereas it is represented that the Washington Aqueduct may allow a discharge of water from the reservoir of a forty-eight-inch iron pipe for mechanical and manufacturing purposes, without affecting the necessary supply for the consumption of the people of Washington and Georgetown; that it would throw open the canal between Rock Creek and Seventh street west for navigation and commerce, remove the sewerage deposits effectually from the bed of the canal, render the water in the reservoir more healthy and acceptable for sanitary usage; that it would tend to develop the natural resources of the District of Columbia, and give to Washington the full benefit of her commercial and manufacturing position; and, finally, that it would cause to be placed along Water street in Georgetown, and along the bank of the said canal, at eligible points, from seventy-five to one hundred separate water-powers, each one not less than forty horse-power, making the aggregate working force of the whole about four thousand horse-power: Therefore,

Mr. Blair asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to pay certain claims arising from the seizure and conversion to the uses of the United States of private personal property after the thirtieth day of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-five. Whereas the President of the United States, by proclamation bearing date May the tenth, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, declared the war at an end; and Whereas by proclamation of May the twenty-ninth, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, he directed the restoration of all private property, "except as to slaves;" and Whereas in obedience to the fifth section of the act of Congress approved July thirteenth, eighteen hundred and sixty-one, and the sixth section of Treasury Regulations approved March thirty-first, eighteen hundred and sixty-three, made in pursuance of said act of Congress, the President, by proclamation of June twenty-fourth, eighteen hundred and sixty-five restored commercial intercourse between all the States of the American Union; and Whereas the Secretary of the Treasury, by the authority of the same issued a circular letter of instructions, of date June twenty-seventh, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, withdrawing the authority of the Treasury Department to seize cotton of any character or description after the thirtieth day of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-five; and Whereas said circular letter of instructions not only forbid the seizure of all cotton after said date, but simply authorized Treasury agents to receive cotton formerly the property of the Confederate States, which had been theretofore surrendered to the military and naval authorities of the United States; and Whereas seizures of such property were made as late as December, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, under the pretext that such cotton was the property of the Confederate States, whereby the pretext of seizure authorized the agent to retain one-fourth of the amount seized; and Whereas the owners of the property, at the time of seizure, had renewed their allegiance to the Government of the United States; and Whereas many of said claimants for such property are barred by the statute of limitations from obtaining redress through the Court of Claims; and Whereas in the United States circuit court for the district of South Carolina, August term, eighteen hundred and sixty-nine, in the case of McLeod versus Callicott, a United States Treasury agent, the Chief Justice of the United States decided that all cotton seized after the thirtieth day of June, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, was unauthorized, and, therefore, illegal, and that the owner of such property was entitled to recover the market value thereof at the time of seizure, with lawful interest from date; and Whereas the Solicitor and the Attorney General of the United States have fully recognized the decision of the Chief Justice of the United States as the law in the premises; and Whereas the Supreme Court of the United States, in the case of the steamer Cotton Plant, unanimously decided that cotton seized after the cessation of hostilities was "not captured or prize cotton," therefore illegal, and directed its restoration; and Whereas the twelfth section of the act of Congress approved July twenty-third, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, directs the Secretary of the Treasury to refund to the lawful owners all moneys erroneously received and erroneously covered into the Treasury; and Whereas the ninth day of April, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, is recognized by the treaty of Washington as the end of the civil war: Therefore,

Mr. Howe asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Public Lands, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Relative to homestead settlers burned out in the States of Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan. Whereas fires in extent unparalleled in the history of the country burned through the newly settled parts of the States of Minnesota, Wisconsin, and Michigan, during the autumn of the year eighteen hundred and seventy-one, whereby many homestead settlers lost their dwellings and all of their personal property, and many were burned to death, and many others were so much burned as to disable them from labor for the present winter, and are unable to rebuild and occupy their lands within a period of six months after said fires had driven them from their homestead: Therefore,

A Bill For the relief of actual settlers upon the Cherokee neutral land in Kansas. Whereas the tract of land in the State of Kansas known as the Cherokee neutral land was held by the Cherokee Nation of Indians, under letters-patent dated December thirty-first, eighteen hundred and thirty-eight, upon condition that if the said Cherokee Nation should become extinct, or abandon the same, the lands thereby granted should revert to the United States; and Whereas the said Cherokee Nation did abandon the said lands on the seventh day of October, anno Domini eighteen hundred and sixty-one, by ceding the same to the late so-called southern confederacy, and ceasing to occupy the said land ever since; and Whereas by section twelve of the act of Congress approved July twenty-second, eighteen hundred and fifty-four, it was enacted "that all the lands to which the Indian title has been or shall be extinguished within said Territories of Kansas and Nebraska shall be subject to the operations of the pre-emption act of fourth of September, eighteen hundred and forty-one;" and Whereas the settlers upon said tract of land have not been permitted to prove up and purchase the lands settled upon and occupied by them because of the refusal of the local land-officers to receive filings for any of the lands in said tract: Therefore,

Whereas the town of Arcata, in Humboldt County, California, was allowed to enter three hundred and twenty acres of land for the use and benefit of the inhabitants of said town, under the act of Congress of May twenty-third, eighteen hundred and forty-four, and said town having applied to enter the southeast quarter of the southwest quarter of section twenty-nine, township six north, range one east, Hamboldt meridian, in addition to said three hundred and twenty acres, for the use and benefit of the inhabitants of the said town, under the act of Congress of March second, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven; and Whereas the Secretary of the Interior refused to allow said town to enter said additional forty acres of land because the said town had already perfected her claim for three hundred and twenty acres; and Whereas said town would have been entitled to enter three hundred and sixty acres of land under and by virtue of the last mentioned act: Therefore,

Mr. Clayton asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To authorize the Secretary of the Interior to receive the funded bonds of the State of Arkansas in exchange for certain bonds now held by him in trust for the Chickasaw Indians, and to issue the agricultural college scrip apportioned to that State and held by him as security for the payment of the said bonds. Whereas the State of Arkansas is indebted to the national fund of the Chickasaw tribe of Indians in the sum of two hundred and fifty-two thousand dollars, principal and interest due and unpaid, upon certain bonds of the said State of Arkansas, held by the Secretary of the Department of the Interior in trust for the said tribe of Indians, which bonds were given as security for a loan from the said fund to the State of Arkansas, and are that portion of the securities belonging to the said fund that were transferred to the Secretary of the Interior by the Secretary of the Treasury, under an act of Congress approved July twenty-seventh, eighteen hundred and sixty-eight, and for the payment of the interest on which bonds no provision is made by the laws of the said State now in force; and Whereas the Secretary of the Department of the Interior refuses to issue the agricultural college scrip apportioned to the said State, under an act of Congress entitled "An act donating public lands to the several States and Territories which may provide colleges for the benefit of agriculture and the mechanic arts," approved July second, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, until the said indebtedness shall be paid, or by an act of Congress he shall be authorized and directed to receive, in lieu thereof, the funded bonds of the present government of the said State, which are ready to be issued, to the full extent of the principal and interest due upon the bonds hereinbefore first mentioned: Therefore,

Mr. Kellogg, from the Committee on Commerce, reported the following bill; which was read and passed to a second reading. A Bill To facilitate the execution of, and to protect certain public works of improvement. Whereas in the prosecution of certain works of river and harbor improvement, undertaken by the Government of the United States, and involving the dredging of river or tidal bars, the engineers charged with the work meet with frequent delay, and the channels excavated with important damage, due to the passage of vessels at unseasonable times, and to the careless or malicious handling of the same; and Whereas this occurs only because there is no one person duly authorized to superintend and direct the passage of vessels, and to hold pilots, ship-masters, and tow-boat captains responsible under a penalty for damage they may cause such public works described: Therefore,

Mr. Sumner asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Relating to the issue of bonds by the authorities of the District of Columbia, and to prevent the increase of the debt of the District. Whereas the legislature of the District of Columbia, by an act entitled "An act making appropriations for improvements and repairs in the District of Columbia, and providing for the payment thereof," approved by the governor of said District July tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-one, authorized the issue of bonds by the financial officers of said District, for the purpose of special improvements, to the amount of four millions of dollars; and Whereas while the question of the legality and validity of such act was pending in the courts of the District, the legislature thereof, prior to the decision of the courts, passed another and similar act, entitled "An act authorizing the District of Columbia to create a debt for special improvements and repairs in said District, by the issuing of four millions of bonds, and levying a tax," and so forth, approved by the governor of said District, August nineteenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-one, also authorizing the issue of four millions of bonds; which act was submitted, to a vote of the people of said District on the twenty-second day of November, eighteen hundred and seventy-one, and was by them on that day approved; and Whereas the legality of the act first named was, subsequent to such approval of the last-named act by the people, sustained by the courts aforesaid, thus apparently legalizing both such acts, and rendering it lawful for the authorities of the District to issue four millions of bonds under each of such acts, and making in the aggregate eight millions instead of four, as was intended; and Whereas grave apprehensions exist in the minds of many of the people of the District that the authorities, in case of an emergency, may issue the full amount of eight millions, which, with the debt now existing, will involve the District in liabilities at once unnecessary and burdensome, and beyond its ability to meet without excessive and ruinous taxation: Therefore,

Dunham, regiment commanded by Colonel James Johnston, and was honorably discharged when peace was proclaimed: Therefore,

Mr. Hitchcock asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Public Lands, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To confirm the title to certain lands on the Fort Kearney military reservation in Fremont County, Iowa. Whereas the following described entries at the Council Bluffs land district, in the State of Iowa, were made on lands which bad been reserved for military purposes for the use of Fort Kearney, by order of the President of the United States, dated the ninth of April, eighteen hundred and forty-six, and therefore illegal, viz: First, the west half of northwest quarter of section thirty, township sixty-eight north, range forty-three west, by John Boulware, per cash certificate number twelve hundred and fifty-six, dated January second, eighteen hundred and fifty-four; secondly, the northwest quarter of southeast quarter of section thirty, township sixty-eight north, range forty-three west, by William C. Fowlkes, per cash certificate number twenty-six hundred and ninety, dated June first, eighteen hundred and fifty-four; thirdly, the southeast quarter of northwest quarter and northeast quarter of south west quarter of section thirty, township sixty-eight, range forty-three west, by William C. Fowlkes, per cash certificate number eighteen hundred and twenty-nine, dated April thirteenth, eighteen hundred and fifty-four; fourthly, the southeast quarter of southwest quarter of section thirty, township sixty-eight, range forty-three west, by Alien A. Brodford, per cash certificate number twenty-six hundred and ninety-one, dated June twenty-first, eighteen hundred and fifty-four; fifthly, lot number one of section thirty-one, township sixty-eight, range forty-three west, by William C. Fowlkes, per cash certificate number six hundred and twenty-three, dated July twenty-seventh, eighteen hundred and fifty-three; sixthly, lots number two, three, and four, of section thirty-one, township sixty-eight, range forty-three west, by Simeon Hargis, per cash certificate number eighteen hundred and thirty, dated April thirteenth, eighteen hundred and fifty-four; seventhly, lot number one, of section thirty-two, township sixty-eight, range forty-three west, by Simeon Hargis, per cash certificate number eighteen hundred and thirty-one, dated April thirteenth, eighteen hundred and fifty-four; eighthly, lot number one, in section twenty-four, township sixty-eight, range forty-four west, by George W. Boulware, per cash certificate number nine hundred and thirteen, dated September twenty-sixth, eighteen hundred and fifty-three; ninthly, lots one and two, of section twenty-five, township sixty-eight, range forty-four west, by George W. Boulware, per cash certificate number nine hundred and twelve, dated September twenty-sixth, eighteen hundred and fifty-three; tenthly, lot number one, of section thirty-six, township sixty-eight, range forty-four west, by George W. Boulware, per cash certificate number nine hundred and fourteen, dated September twenty-sixth, eighteen hundred and fifty-three; eleventh, the southeast quarter of section, twenty-five, township sixty-eight, range forty-four west, by George W. Boulware, per cash certificate number three hundred and four, dated July ninth, eighteen hundred and fifty-three; twelfthly, the west half of southwest quarter of section thirty, township sixty-eight, range forty-three west, selected as swamp-land; and Whereas the Secretary of War, by letter under date of the eleventh of March, eighteen hundred and seventy, advised the Secretary of the Interior "that the United States military reservation at Fort Kearney, on the Missouri River, is no longer required for military purposes;" and Whereas the register and the receiver at Council Bluffs, Iowa, have reported, under date of May twenty-third, eighteen hundred and seventy, to the General Land-Office, that, due notice having been given to all persons having any interest in the same to appear before them on the eighteenth day of May, eighteen hundred, and seventy, and show cause why the above-named entries should not be confirmed by act of Congress, no adverse claimants appeared before them: Therefore,

Hodge, and Amelia S. Hodge, now Mrs. George Packard, are the sole surviving representatives of the said Nehemiah Hodge: Therefore,

Mr. Pratt asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Public Lands, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To release the title of the United States to certain lands in Michigan City, Indiana. Whereas Isaac C. Elston, on the twenty-fifth day of June, eighteen hundred and thirty-five, agreed to donate to the United States a piece or parcel of ground in Michigan City, in the State of Indiana, for a light-house, said piece or parcel of land to be two hundred and sixty feet long and one hundred and seventy-five feet wide, the courses of the lines to run parallel to the streets in said city. That on that day the said Elston, intending to convey the land so donated, executed a deed to the United States for a piece or parcel of ground, and by mistake described it as follows: "All that tract or parcel of land situate, lying, and being in the county of Laporte, in the State of Indiana, and in and part of section twenty-nine in township thirty-eight north, range four west, bounded as follows, namely: beginning at a point twenty feet west of a stake stuck for the site of a light-house, and from thence south one hundred and thirty feet to a stake, and from thence east one hundred and seventy-five feet to a stake, and from thence north to Lake Michigan two hundred and sixty feet; thence west with the margin of the lake one hundred and seventy-five feet, and from thence south to the place of beginning." That the United States soon after the execution of said deed took possession of the ground first above described and so intended to be conveyed, and built a light-house thereon, inclosed it with a fence, and thence hitherto have held the exclusive possession thereof, and have never asserted title to any other property under said deed; and Whereas the said Elston was the owner of all the land adjoining said ground and retained possession thereof, and afterward sold and conveyed the same to innocent purchasers, who, or those claiming under such conveyances, caused the same to be platted and laid out into town lots as an addition to Michgan City, and which said town lots were laid out with reference to the land so taken possession of and fenced by the United States, and which said land and town lots are now held and possessed in good faith by the remote vendees of said Elston: Now therefore, For the purpose of correcting said mistake and releasing all right, title, or interest which the United States may have by virtue of the error in said deed of said Elston: Therefore,

Langford is willing to sell the said tract of land to the United States upon being paid a just compensation for the same: Therefore,

Mr. Casserly asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of the former occupants of the present military reservation at Point San Jose, in the city and county of San Francisco. Whereas by the act of Congress of July first, eighteen hundred and seventy, relinquishing the right and title of the United States to the military reservation at Point San Jose, except the portion thereof now held as such reservation, the lands thereby relinquished were restored to parties who had been misled by the action of the Government in withdrawing its appeal from the decree of the board of land commissioners of the United States confirming the title of the city of San Francisco to lands embracing said reservation, and were in the bona-fide possession thereof when the military authorities went into the occupancy thereof; and Whereas the persons dispossessed by the military authorities of the portion so excepted in said act bad in every respect the same equitable claims to the lands formerly occupied by them, and were excluded from the relief granted by said act solely because the said lands are required for military purposes; and Whereas the buildings and improvements erected by the former occupants of the lands within the present limits of said reservation are useful for the purposes of the Government, and their existence has saved a considerable expense to the United States: Therefore,

column10: Mr. Rice asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs, and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of the freedmen of the Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations. Whereas in the third article of the treaty made and concluded on the twenty-eighth day of April, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, between the United States and the Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations of Indians, it is provided that the sum of three hundred thousand dollars (the consideration for the cession of certain territory by said nations to the United States) shall be invested and held by the United States, at an interest of not less than five per centum, in trust for the said Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations, to be paid to the same in the proportion of three-fourths to the former and one-fourth to the latter immediately upon the enactment of such laws, rules, and regulations by their respective legislatures as may be necessary to give all persons of African descent, resident in said nations at the date of the treaty of Fort Smith, and their descendants, previously held in slavery among said nations, all the rights, privileges, and immunities, including the right of suffrage, of citizens of said nations; and on failure to pass such laws, rules, and regulations by the legislatures of said nations, respectively, within two years from the ratification of said treaty, the said sum of three hundred thousand dollars shall cease to be held in trust for the said Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations, and shall be held for the use and benefit of such of said persons of African descent as the United States shall remove from said Territory, in such manner as the United States shall deem proper, the United States agreeing, within ninety days from the expiration of said treaty, to remove from said nations, all such persons of African descent as may be willing to remove; and Whereas, further, the said Choctaw and Chickasaw legislatures have heretofore refused, and still refuse, to pass such laws, rules, and regulations as aforesaid, but have respectively passed enactments declaring it to be the unanimous consent of said legislatures that the United States shall hold said three hundred thousand dollars for the benefit of said freedmen, and directing notice to be given to the United States that it is their wish that said persons of African descent be removed by the United States beyond the limits of said Choctaw and Chickasaw Nations respectively, according to the provisions of article three of the treaty aforesaid; and it being the desire of said freedmen to remove beyond the limits of said nations, and to receive the said sum of three hundred thousand dollars: Therefore,

Mr. Carpenter asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of Edward H. Wilson. Whereas Edward H. Wilson did, on the tenth day of July, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, institute suit against the Bank of Louisiana, in the circuit court of the State of Alabama, at Montgomery, by attachment, which was levied upon three hundred and forty-six bales of cotton, in two separate lots, one of one hundred and eighty-two bales and the other of one hundred and fifty-four bales; and afterward, by order of said circuit court, Josiah Morris replevied said cotton; and both of said lots of cotton were subsequently seized and, by order of the United States district court for the middle district of Alabama, confiscated; and after such seizure, and before said order of confiscation, said Morris replevied said lot of one hundred and fifty-four bales; and subsequently John Hardy, marshal of said district court, sold said one hundred and eighty-two bales of cotton, pursuant to said order, for the sum of seventeen thousand three hundred and eighty-one dollars and five cents, and paid the same over to the clerk of said court, and the said district court rendered judgment against said Josiah Morris, on his replevin bond, for the sum of twenty-five thousand and sixty-nine dollars and seventy cents, the value of said one hundred and fifty-four bales replevied as aforesaid, which amount was paid by said Josiah Morris to said marshal, John Hardy; and Whereas said marshal and clerk deposited said moneys in the First National Bank of Selma, a bank which had been duly designated by the Secretary of the Treasury as a depository of public moneys for the State of Alabama, in obedience to orders of the Secretary of the Treasury; and Whereas, upon an appeal by said Josiah Morris to the Supreme Court of the United States, said orders of said district court were reversed, and said cases were remanded and afterward dismissed in the said district court; and Whereas the said Edward H. Wilson recovered final judgment in said suit against the Bank of Louisiana, on the twelfth day of July, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven, for the sum of one hundred and six thousand nine hundred and sixty-nine dollars, by virtue of which judgment said Wilson is lawfully entitled to the money so realized on said cotton, amounting in the aggregate to the sum of forty-two thousand four hundred and fifty dollars and seventy-five cents; and Whereas no part of said moneys so deposited by said clerk and marshal was ever withdrawn from said bank; and Whereas after said deposits said bank became insolvent, and a decree of the dissolution thereof was entered in the district court of the United States for the middle district of Alabama; and Whereas the assets of said bank came into the hands of Cornelius Cadle, junior, by virtue of an appointment to receive the same, issued by the Comptroller of the Currency of the United States, and from time to time the said Cadle has paid over to the Treasurer of the United States the moneys received by him: Therefore,

Whereas in December, eighteen hundred and seventy, Major Samuel Ross, United States Army, unassigned, was examined by a retiring board at San Francisco, California, and found disabled for active duty on account of wounds received in battle; and Whereas no official action having been taken to retire from active service the said Ross on the proceedings of said retiring board, and the said Ross being a supernumerary officer was honorably mustered out of service as such on or about January second, eighteen hundred and seventy-one; and Whereas on or about March second, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, the said Ross was re-appointed an officer of the United States Army, as second lieutenant, with a view of being retired from active service on account of said disability: Therefore,

A Bill For the relief of John H. Hutchinson and Thomas H. Hutchinson, of De Witt, Arkansas County, Arkansas. Whereas John H. Hutchinson and Thomas H. Hutchinson, of De Witt, Arkansas County, Arkansas, have made entries of certain tracts of land, viz: South half of south half of section two, township five, range four West, and east half of east half of section twenty-three, township five south, range four west, respectively, and for causes beyond their control have failed to make settlement within the time prescribed by the homestead laws, and now pray for relief to enable them to retain the land: Therefore,

Mr. Kellogg asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of Henry Ware. Whereas agents of the Government of the United States seized seven hundred and fifty-eight hales of cotton at Shreveport, in the State of Louisiana, on the first day of December, eighteen hundred and sixty-five, the property of Henry Ware, then of Harrison County, Texas, now of Louisiana, on the false pretext that fifty-five bales thereof had been the property of the late confederate government, and under certain proceedings instituted in the State court for the recovery of said cotton by the owner thereof, the sheriff took possession of the same and was immediately thereafter forcibly dispossessed by United States troops, by order of the commander of the post of Shreveport; and said agents sent said cotton to New Orleans where it was held by the United States until the sixth day of March, eighteen hundred and sixty-six; and Whereas while said cotton was so held by the United States, at New Orleans, the owner thereof twice petitioned the department commander, Major General E. R. L. Canby, for permission to institute an action in the United States district court for the recovery thereof, and was refused, and was assured by said department commander that the possession of said cotton would be forcibly maintained; and Whereas when the United States returned said cotton to its lawful owner, said Henry Ware, it was deficient in quantity and inferior in quality, and was worth fifty-three thousand nine hundred and seventy-one dollars and sixty-one cents less than when so seized, and the United States compelled said Ware to pay excessive and unlawful charges on said cotton, amounting to ten thousand eight hundred and forty-two dollars and thirty-one cents, as the condition of the restoratian thereof; and Whereas the owner of said cotton having, on the seventh day of April, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, instituted an action for the recovery of the difference in the value of the same at the time of the seizure and the time of the restoration thereof, and also of said excessive charges, against the agents of the United States, in a State court of Louisiana, the said department commander, on the twenty-fourth day of April, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, issued his order prohibiting said court from entertaining jurisdiction of said action, but afterward, on the fourteenth day of May, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, authorized said court to entertain such jurisdiction, and the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States employed attorneys and counsel who defended said action, and judgment therein was rendered for said Ware for the difference in the value of said cotton when seized and when restored, and for the charges so paid, amounting in the aggregate to sixty-four thousand eight hundred and thirteen dollars and ninety-two cents, with interest and costs, and no part of said judgment has ever been paid: Therefore,

Whereas the several treaties between the United States and the Cherokee, Choctaw, Chickasaw, Creek, and Seminole Nations of Indians, concluded in eighteen hundred and sixty-six, provide for the establishment of a United States court in the Indian country, commonly known as the Indian Territory, as follows, namely, the Cherokee treaty, article thirteen: "The Cherokees also agree that a court or courts may be established by the United States in said Territory, with such jurisdiction and organized in such manner as may be prescribed by law: Provided, That the judicial tribunals of the nation shall be allowed to retain exclusive jurisdiction in all civil and criminal causes arising within their country in which members of the nation, by nativity or adoption, shall be the only parties, or where the cause of action shall arise in the Cherokee Nation, except as otherwise provided in this treaty." Mr. Wright asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Claims, and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of Joseph Nock. Whereas Joseph Nock, of Washington, District of Columbia, (formerly of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania,) was the inventor and patentee of certain valuable improvements in self-locking padlocks for mail-service; and Whereas the Postmaster General entered into contract with the said Joseph Nock to manufacture and furnish all of the padlocks for the entire postal service of the United States; and Whereas in order to have exclusive control of the first and most valuable patent for self-locking padlocks, required the said Joseph Nock to assign all of his right, title, and interest to his patent of July sixteenth, eighteen hundred and thirty-nine, to the United States; and Whereas before any locks were delivered on said contract, the Postmaster General annulled the contract and refused to reassign the said valuable patent to Joseph Nock, thereby preventing him from enjoying the benefits of said valuable invention or of disposing of it for several hundred thousand dollars, as he had opportunity to do; and Whereas the Post-Office Department subsequently contracted for and was supplied with over one hundred thousand self-locking padlocks, embodying said Joseph Nock's patent fully, many of which are now in use: Therefore,

Mr. Cragin, from the Committee on Naval Affairs, submitted a report, (No. 179,) accompanied by the following bill; which was read and passed to a second reading. A Bill To establish an iron-ship building yard on the waters falling into the Atlantic, and an iron-ship building-yard on the Mississippi or one of its tributaries, and to afford facilities to the Navy. Whereas the International Steamship Company have made to the Navy Department the following proposals to create iron-ship building yards and docks, by which iron naval and commercial steamers can be built as cheaply in the United States as in Europe; and to establish semi-weekly transatlantic steamers without other subsidy than the postages arising from mail-matter, as now authorized by law: And whereas the Western Iron-Ship and Boat-Building Company have proposed to erect an iron-ship and boat-building yard on the Mississippi River, or one of its tributaries, on the same plans, terms, and conditions as those of the International Steamship Company; said proposals are set forth in Senate Miscellaneous Document Number One hundred and forty-three, of present session: Now, therefore, to secure the positive construction of said yards to aid American commerce, and to afford greater facilities for the construction and repair of naval ships and machinery:

Ordered to be printed. Amendment Intended to be proposed by Mr. Morrill, of Maine, to the bill (S. 1098) to establish an iron-ship building yard on the waters falling into the Atlantic, and an iron-ship building yard on the Mississippi or one of its tributaries, and to afford facilities to the Navy, viz: Insert the following as additional sections:

A Bill To establish a national university. Whereas it is the duty of every government to secure to its people facilities for the highest culture, no less than the means of elementary education; and Whereas it is believed that such facilities cannot otherwise be so well provided for the people of this nation as by founding a university so comprehensive in plan as to include every department of learning, so high as to embrace the limits of human knowledge, so national in aim as to promote concord among the people of all sections, and so related to other institutions as to promote their efficiency, and with them form a complete system of American education: Therefore,

Reported by Mr. Ferry, of Connecticut, without amendment. A Bill For the relief of James D.Willoughby, of Vineland, New Jersey Whereas letters-patent of the United States were issued to James D. Willoughby for an improvement in seed-planters, August third, eighteen hundred and fifty-eight, number twenty-one thousand one hundred and two, which said letters-patent do expire August third, eighteen hundred and seventy-two; and Whereas James D. Willoughby aforesaid, the inventor, did visit Washington City, on or about April tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, for the purpose of applying for extension of his said letters-patent, and that the time allotted by law in which to make his said application was limited to May third, instant; and Whereas the said James D. Willoughby was, upon his arrival, prostrated with an attack of brain-fever until the time allotted had passed in which to make his said application according to law; and Whereas his failure to so apply was caused by no fault or negligence of his own: Therefore,

Mr. Ferry, of Connecticut, from the Committee on Patents, reported the following bill; which was read and passed to a second reading. A Bill For the relief of Hiram W. Hayden. Whereas, on the sixteenth day of December, in the year eighteen hundred and fifty-one, letters-patent of the United States were granted to Hiram W. Hayden for machinery for making kettles and articles of like character from disks of metal, which were extended by the Commissioner of Patents, and were afterward, on the thirteenth day of February, in the year eighteen hundred sixty-six, re-issued to the said Hayden, and were afterward, to wit, on the twenty-fourth day of May, in the year eighteen hundred and seventy, surrendered and re-issued to the Waterbury Brass Company, as assignees of the said Hiram W. Hayden, in two divisions, numbered, respectively, three thousand nine hundred and ninety-five and three thousand nine hundred and ninety-six, and which will expire on the sixteenth day of December, in the year eighteen hundred and seventy-two; and Whereas it appears that the said inventions and machinery of the said Hiram W. Hayden are novel, and that he is the original and first inventor thereof, and that the same are of great value and importance to the public, and that the said Hiram W. Hayden has received no adequate reward for the service conferred on the public by said invention: Therefore,

column10: Mr. Buckingham, from the Committee on Indian Affairs, reported the following bill; which was read and passed to a second reading. A Bill To enable the Commissioner of Indian Affairs to purchase and pay for certain improvements within the Nez Perce Indian reservation in the Territory of Idaho. Whereas, by the tenth article of the treaty concluded with the Nez Perce tribe of Indians, June eleventh, eighteen hundred and fifty-five, it was agreed that the tract of land then occupied by William Craig should not be considered a part of the reservation set apart for them by said treaty, except that the same should be subject to the intercourse act in common with the other lands of the reservation, in consideration of the fact that said Craig had consented to reside among them as their friend and adviser; and Whereas the said Craig, and, since his death, his legal representatives, have cultivated and otherwise improved the tract of land in question; and Whereas the right of personal occupancy of the same, acquired under the treaty referred to, ceased with the death of said Craig; and Whereas the improvements upon said tract, as aforesaid, are required for the use of the Nez Perce tribe of Indians: Therefore,
Ordered to be printed with the amendment of the House of Representatives. An Act Relating to the limitation of steam-pressure on towing and freight boats on the Mississippi River and its tributaries.

Mr. Buckingham asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Appropriations, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Directing the Secretary of War to deliver to Fisk Mills, sculptor, condemned ordnance, to be used in the casting of the equestrian statue of the late General Rawlins, and making appropriation for the erection of the same upon the public grounds. Whereas Congress by an act, approved July fourteenth, eighteen hundred and seventy, placed at the disposal of the President of the United States certain condemned ordnance, to be applied in the execution of a bronze equestrian monument to the memory of the late General John A. Rawlins, after the likeness of the cast taken in plaster from the face of the deceased, by order of Quartermaster General M. C. Meigs, and provided for the erection of the same upon the public grounds in the city of Washington, the said ordnance to be delivered when the plaster model for the statue should be completed; and Whereas the said plaster model is now completed and ready for casting, and proves to be not only a faithful semblance of the distinguished soldier but a great artistic achievement: Therefore,

column10: Mr. Buckingham asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, and ordered to be printed. A Bill Relating to the payment of bounties to the Fifth Regiment Connecticut Volunteers. Whereas certain members of the Fifth Connecticut Volunteer Infantry, in good faith, enlisted for three years' service prior to July twenty-second, eighteen hundred and sixty-one, for the purpose of offering their services to the United States, but were not mustered into the service of the United States until July twenty-third, eighteen hundred and sixty-one; and Whereas there was no agreement between the United States and the State that they should be recognized as in the service of the United States from the dates of their enlistment under the State, thus depriving them of the benefits of the act of April twenty-second, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, entitled "An act in relation to bounties:" Therefore,

Mr. Buckingham asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, and ordered to be printed. Reported by Mr. Morrill, of Maine, with an amendment, viz: Insert the part printed in italics. A Bill Relating to the payment of bounties to the Fifth Regiment Connecticut Volunteers. Whereas certain members of the Fifth Connecticut Volunteer Infantry, in good faith, enlisted for three years' service prior to July twenty-second, eighteen hundred and sixty-one, for the purpose of offering their services to the United States, but were not mustered into the service of the United States until July twenty-third, eighteen hundred and sixty-one; and Whereas there was no agreement between the United States and the State that they should be recognized as in the service of the United States from the dates of their enlistment under the State, thus depriving them of the benefits of the act of April twenty-second, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, entitled "An act in relation to bounties:" Therefore,

Mr. Harlan asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Public Lands, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To carry into effect the provisions of section four of an act entitled "An act making a grant of lands in the State of Iowa, in alternate sections, to aid in the construction of certain railroads in said State," approved May fifteenth, eighteen hundred and fifty-six. Whereas under an act of Congress passed June second, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, being an act making a grant of lands to certain railroads in the State of Iowa, said act being supplemental to an act passed May fifteenth, eighteen hundred and fifty-six, making a grant of lands to the State of Iowa "to aid in the construction of certain railroads in said State," wherein a part of said lands were to inure to the benefit of the Cedar Rapids and Missouri River Railroad, with certain conditions and restrictions; and Whereas said company having accepted said grant of lands along the line known as the "forty-second parallel route," commencing at Lyons, in Clinton County, State of Iowa, thence running as nearly as practicable along said parallel to the Missouri River, asked and obtained, by virtue of the act of June second, eighteen hundred and sixty-four, permission to change its line of road so as to make an immediate connection with the Union Pacific road, at or near Council Bluffs, and said act provided that in case the main line shall be so changed or modified as not to reach the Missouri River at or near the forty-second parallel north latitude, it shall be the duty of said company, within a reasonable time after the construction of its road to the Missouri River, to construct a branch-road, to some point in Monona County, in or at Onawa City, in Monona County, and to aid in its construction the same amount of lands per mile are hereby granted as for the main line, and the same shall be reserved and certified in the same manner; and Whereas the reasonable time having expired since the completion of their main line to the Missouri River, and said branch-road to Onawa City not having been commenced: Therefore,

Mr. Hitchcock asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To provide for the removal of the Otoe Indians of Nebraska to the Indian Territory. Whereas by act of Congress approved June tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, entitled "An act for the relief of certain tribes of Indians in the Northern superintendency," the Secretary of the Interior was authorized to sell a portion of the lands of the Otoe Indians, the consent of said Indians being first obtained in open council; and Whereas said Otoe Indians have in council refused to give such consent, but have expressed their desire to sell the whole of said reservation and to remove to the Indian Territory, and have during the past season sent a delegation of said tribe to said Territory for the purpose of examining the country and selecting for themselves a home; and Whereas the cultivation, settlement, and improvement of these lands, and the consequent development and prosperity of that portion of the West, would be best attained by giving these lands into the possession of actual settlers rather than speculators: Therefore,

A Bill To authorize the Secretary of the Interior to negotiate with the Creek Indians for the cession of a portion of their reservation occupied by friendly Indians. Whereas by the third article of the treaty concluded with the Creek Indians June fourteenth, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, said Indians ceded to the United States, for the settlement of friendly Indians and freedmen, the west half of their entire domain, to be divided by a line running north and south; and Whereas the recent survey of said line, made in conformity with the provisions of said treaty, includes within the limits of the Creek reservation, east of said line, some of the improvements made on a reservation selected on what was supposed to be the Creek ceded lands for the Seminole tribe of Indians, which reservation is provided for in their treaty of March first, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, and also some of the improvements of the Sacs and Foxes of the Mississippi tribe of Indians, made on a reservation intended to be established in accordance with the provisions of their treaty of February eighteenth, eighteen hundred and sixty-seven; and Whereas said improvements have been made upon said lands by and for the aforesaid Indians, who have settled thereupon in good faith, in accordance with treaty stipulations; and Whereas it is necessary in order to secure these improvements to said Indians, and to insure them suitable reservations, that the lands occupied thereby should be granted to them: Therefore,

A Bill To repeal an act entitled "An act for the relief of certain Indians in the Central superintendency," approved June tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, and to settle by commission all rights, and equities respecting the property to which said act refers. Whereas by an act entitled "An act for the relief of certain Indians in the Central superintendency," approved June tenth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, the Secretary of the Interior was authorized and directed to appoint three commissioners, and to take an inventory of, appraise, and sell certain lands, bonds, notes, accounts, contracts, mortgages, and other property or assets held or acquired in any manner under a trust in respect to education, created and confirmed by treaties with the Ottawa Indians of Blanchard's Fork and Roche de Boeuf, proclaimed July twenty-eighth, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, and October fourteenth, eighteen hundred and sixty-eight, and to pay the proceeds of such sale to the several members of the said tribe, their heirs or assigns, per capita; and Whereas counter claims of rights and equities in said lands, bonds, notes, accounts, contracts, mortgages, and other property or assets having been set forth and affirmed by the trustees under said trust, and by the American Baptist Home Mission Society, the Secretary of the Interior, having appointed said commissioners, and having obtained through them the said inventory and appraisal, has referred to Congress the question of further legislation; and Whereas representatives of all the said parties have united in an agreement to make friendly application to Congress for legislation providing for the ascertainment, severance, and satisfaction, by commission, of the equitable interests of the contending parties: Now, therefore, in order that the most perfect justice may be done in the premises to all the said parties,

Mr. Hitchcock asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To amend an act entitled "An act to enable honorably discharged soldiers and sailors, their widows and orphan children, to acquire homesteads on the public lands of the United States," and the amendments thereto. Whereas by act of Congress entitled "An act to enable honorably discharged soldiers and sailors, their widows and orphan children, to acquire homesteads on the public lands of the United States," approved April fourth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, and by the amendment thereto, approved June eighth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, it is provided that said soldiers and sailors, their widows and orphan children, shall have the right to enter homesteads of one hundred and sixty acres each upon what are called and known as "double minimum" lands, or lands within the limits of railroad land grants; and Whereas many soldiers and sailors had, prior to the passage of said act and the amendments thereto, entered homesteads within said limits, not exceeding eighty acres each, and are unable, under the terms of said act and amendment, and the rulings of the General Land-Office, to avail themselves of the advantages of entering one hundred and sixty acres of said "double minimum" land; and Whereas such discrimination against the pioneer soldiers and sailors is uncalled for and unjust: Therefore,

Mr. Wright asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Public Lands, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To authorize Robert Coles to locate certain swamp-land indemnity scrip therein named. Whereas it appearing that in accordance with the laws of the State of Iowa the board of supervisors of Lucas County, in said State, on the second day of November, eighteen hundred and sixty-two, entered into a contract with Robert Coles, conveying to him all the right, title, and interest which may accrue to Lucas County under the laws of the State of Iowa to the swamp-lands situated in said county, or indemnification for lands sold for cash, or located with land-warrants after the passage of the act of twenty-eighth September, eighteen hundred and fifty, under the act of March second, eighteen hundred and fifty-five; and it further appearing that the necessary proof to secure said indemnification was on file in the General Land-Office as early as the month of June, eighteen hundred and sixty, and action was not had thereon, owing to the failure of the surveyor-general to certify up the list of swamp selections made by the proper agent, as required by the Secretary of the Interior, until after the passage of the act of March fifth, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, for the relief of Lucas and other counties in the State of Iowa, when on the twenty-eighth day of March, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, "swamp indemnity scrip number ninety-two," for two thousand three hundred and sixty-three acres and twenty-six hundredths of an acre was issued to the State of Iowa under the act of second March, eighteen hundred and fifty-five, and on the fifteenth day of April, eighteen hundred and seventy-two, swamp indemnity scrip number ninety-three was also issued for thirty-six acres and thirty-six hundredths of an acre, all for swamp-lands in Lucas County, State of Iowa, and located with land-warrants after the passage of the act of twenty-eighth September, eighteen hundred and fifty; and it further appearing that according to the laws of the State of Iowa the said Robert Coles is duly authorized to locate said scrip on behalf of the same; and it further appearing that at the time said contract was entered into between the board of supervisors and Robert Coles, as above stated, there were large quantities of unsold public lands in the State of Iowa; and it appearing that at this time, and ever since said scrip was issued, there are no public lands in said State of Iowa upon which the same can be located: Therefore,

column11: Committee on the Revision of the Laws of the United States

column10: Mr. Nye asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Mines and Mining, and ordered to be printed. A Bill To aid in the construction of the Sutro tunnel from the proceeds of the sale of mineral lands. Whereas our public lands contain mines of the precious metals which are unsurpassed in extent, and can, with proper development, be made speedily to enhance the value of all property, and thereby relieve the burdens of the people; and Whereas a wise policy indicates that the revenue derived from our mineral lands should, to some extent, be devoted again to the much-needed development of that important interest; and Whereas Congress, by an act approved July twenty-fifth, eighteen hundred and sixty-six, authorized the construction of a draining and exploring tunnel to the Comstock lode, in the State of Nevada, and granted to Adolph Sutro certain rights and privileges, which have been assigned, transferred, and set over to a corporation, duly organized under the laws of the State of California, and known as the Sutro Tunnel Company; and Whereas great benefits will accrue to the people of the United States from the construction of said tunnel, which, as a great geological survey, penetrating into an argentiferous mountain to a greater depth than has yet been reached by any similar work in the world, will establish the value of our mineral domain; and Whereas the principal wealth of our mineral regions consists in low-grade ores, which can only be utilized by means of improved reduction, concentration, and smelting works, for the erection of which extraordinary facilities exist at the mouth of said tunnel; and Whereas this work bears a national character, and its magnitude is beyond the capacity of private enterprise, and the security offered to the Government is ample for the repayment of any sums to be advanced under this act: Therefore,

Mr. Nye asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Mines and Mining, and ordered to be printed. Whereas the great expense of providing facilities for the education of the blind preclude the investment of private capital; and Whereas there have not, therefore, been published a series of textbooks and sufficient general literature in raised print, or illustrative apparatus addressed to the touch, nor means of instruction in the higher branches of a liberal education; and Whereas a responsible organization has been incorporated in the District of Columbia, whose object is to furnish the aforesaid facilities to the blind of the whole country; and Whereas considerable funds and subscriptions have been pledged in furtherance of the said organization; and Whereas the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars will enable the board of regents of the said national institution to place it on a permanent basis: Now, therefore,

Mr. Hitchcock asked and, by unanimous consent, obtained leave to bring in the following bill; which was read twice, referred to the Committee on Indian Affairs, and ordered to be printed. A Bill For the relief of persons for damages sustained by reason of Indian depredations. Whereas during the past twelve years many depredations and injuries, both to persons and property, have been committed upon our frontier settlers within the States of Kansas and Nebraska and the adjacent Territories; and Whereas many persons living upon the lands of the United States to which the Indian title had been extinguished within the limits of said States and Territories, and many others lawfully engaged in the transportation of merchandise along the lines of travel between the Missouri River and the western Territories have been attacked and robbed by said Indians, and a large amount of property has been destroyed; and Whereas it is just and equitable that such persons should be re-imbursed for the damages sustained as aforesaid: Therefore,
